Award.AwardTitle: Precision Microprofile Extrusion with a Wall Slip Condition

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop and investigate a novel precision microprofile extrusion process, the basis of which uses a field-induced material transport mechanism for creating a conformal fluidic layer on the microextrudate. To create a thin conformal fluidic layer, a polymer blended with a small amount of miscible low-molecular-weight or oligomeric additive is extruded through a long die channel, causing enhanced phase separation to occur. This shear-induced phase separation, in turn, causes the low-molecular-weight fluid to migrate to the die surface, thus forming a conformal fluidic layer and creating a wall-slip condition for the polymer extrudate. Due to wall slip, the flow stresses and thus the amount of die swell are minimized. Furthermore, due to the inherent miscibility of the fluidic layer with the polymer extrudate the surface tension effect is greatly reduced or eliminated. The main research activities will be 1) to demonstrate the technical feasibility of this novel microprofile extrusion process, 2) to gain a fundamental understanding of field-induced phase separation in microprofile extrusion and, 3) to formulate a predicative model for this new process.

Successful complication of this research will lead to a novel manufacturing process for precision microprofile extrusion. Precision microprofiles offer unique functions (e.g., enhanced surface activities, diffractive effects, wave transmission efficiency, etc.) that cannot be realized by their circular counterparts. Although precision microprofiles are highly desirable in the emerging biochemical, biomedical and telecommunication industries, a capable process for fabricating them is yet to be developed. The new process would therefore fill a technical gap and create new market sectors for a wide variety of applications. Moreover, the knowledge gained on the enhancement of field-induced phase migration would be particularly useful in the development of other innovative processes, potentially in the areas of coating, lubrication, and selective surface modification.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this award is to develop and investigate a novel precision microprofile extrusion process, the basis of which uses a field-induced material transport mechanism for creating a conformal fluidic layer on the microextrudate. To create a thin conformal fluidic layer, a polymer blended with a small amount of miscible low-molecular-weight or oligomeric additive is extruded through a long die channel, causing enhanced phase separation to occur. This shear-induced phase separation, in turn, causes the low-molecular-weight fluid to migrate to the die surface, thus forming a conformal fluidic layer and creating a wall-slip condition for the polymer extrudate. Due to wall slip, the flow stresses and thus the amount of die swell are minimized. Furthermore, due to the inherent miscibility of the fluidic layer with the polymer extrudate the surface tension effect is greatly reduced or eliminated.

The primary research activities accomplished at Georgia Tech included 1) Investigated a phase-separation microextrusion process with low molecular weight polymer as additive in high molecular weight polymer melt; 2) Developed simulation capabilities for predicting the shape changes in microprofile extrusion; 3) Studied deformation induced phase separation in compatible polymer blends with components of vastly different molecular weights; 4) Established a rheological model for such compatible polymer blends. These activities led to the development of an innovative phase-separation process for polymer processing. Applying to microextrusion, one can add a small amount of low molecular weight polymer to create a thin lubrication layer and improve extrusion quality. The new method further allows the creation of low molecular weight coatings on thin films and fibers in a single-step process. Fundamental understandings were gained on phase separation and rheology of compatible polymer blends.

By making polymer segregation a more rapid process than is possible for thermal processes, the separation of polymers from blends is reduced in time scale. In addition to applications in microprofile extrusion, this could be particularly useful in recycling processes involving polymer blend waste. Currently, blended polymers are very difficult to recycle; blends of compatible polymers, even more so.  These processes significantly expand the range of materials that may be possible to recycle. Moreover, the knowledge gained on the enhancement of field-induced phase migration would be particularly useful in the development of other innovative processes, potentially in the areas of coating, lubrication, and selective surface modification. The research activities that address theoretical study supported by accurate experimental data obtained from advanced characterizations would provide an excellent case study where deep fundamental understanding could greatly promote the development of new viable processes.


Last Modified: 10/08/2012
Modified by: Donggang Yao
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The research objective of this award is to develop and investigate a novel precision microprofile extrusion process, the basis of which uses a field-induced material transport mechanism for creating a conformal fluidic layer on the microextrudate. To create a thin conformal fluidic layer, a polymer blended with a small amount of miscible low-molecular-weight or oligomeric additive is extruded through a long die channel, causing enhanced phase separation to occur. This shear-induced phase separation, in turn, causes the low-molecular-weight fluid to migrate to the die surface, thus forming a conformal fluidic layer and creating a wall-slip condition for the polymer extrudate. Due to wall slip, the flow stresses and thus the amount of die swell are minimized. Furthermore, due to the inherent miscibility of the fluidic layer with the polymer extrudate the surface tension effect is greatly reduced or eliminated. The primary research activities accomplished at Georgia Tech included 1) Investigated a phase-separation microextrusion process with low molecular weight polymer as additive in high molecular weight polymer melt; 2) Developed simulation capabilities for predicting the shape changes in microprofile extrusion; 3) Studied deformation induced phase separation in compatible polymer blends with components of vastly different molecular weights; 4) Established a rheological model for such compatible polymer blends. These activities led to the development of an innovative phase-separation process for polymer processing. Fundamental understandings were gained on phase separation and rheology of compatible polymer blends. By making polymer segregation a more rapid process than is possible for thermal processes, the separation of polymers from blends is reduced in time scale. In addition to applications in microprofile extrusion, this could be particularly useful in recycling processes involving polymer blend waste. Currently, blended polymers are very difficult to recycle; blends of compatible polymers, even more so. These processes significantly expand the range of materials that may be possible to recycle. Moreover, the knowledge gained on the enhancement of field-induced phase migration would be particularly useful in the development of other innovative processes, potentially in the areas of coating, lubrication, and selective surface modification. The research activities that address theoretical study supported by accurate experimental data obtained from advanced characterizations would provide an excellent case study where deep fundamental understanding could greatly promote the development of new viable processes.
